articles.headline: Why It’s So Hard to Calculate What You’ll Pay for College
articles.snippet: Many colleges offer discounts via a system that’s come to be known as merit aid. But it’s not easy to decipher, as a trip to four schools reveals.
articles.abstract: Many colleges offer discounts via a system that’s come to be known as merit aid. But it’s not easy to decipher, as a trip to four schools reveals.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALONG THE MASSACHUSETTS TURNPIKE — It’s high season for the people with some of the toughest jobs in higher education.

articles.headline: Union Is Formed at Los Angeles Times and Publisher Put on Leave
articles.snippet: By a 248-44 vote, newsroom employees defied an anti-union campaign by Tronc management. Later, Ross Levinsohn went on a leave of absence following harassment allegations.
articles.abstract: By a 248-44 vote, newsroom employees defied an anti-union campaign by Tronc management. Later, Ross Levinsohn went on a leave of absence following harassment allegations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Journalists at The Los Angeles Times voted overwhelmingly to form a union despite aggressive opposition from the paper’s management team, reversing more than a century of anti-union sentiment at one of the biggest newspapers in the country.

articles.headline: Bank of America Executive Departs After Misconduct Claim
articles.snippet: The executive, Omeed Malik, was accused of inappropriate sexual conduct with a young woman, according to people briefed on the bank’s investigation.
articles.abstract: The executive, Omeed Malik, was accused of inappropriate sexual conduct with a young woman, according to people briefed on the bank’s investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: A senior executive at Bank of America in New York departed last week after an internal investigation into a young female banker’s accusation of inappropriate sexual conduct, according to people at the bank who were briefed on the investigation.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Shutdown? It Could Be Forgotten in a Trumpian Flash
articles.snippet: As Democrats pushed the government toward a shutdown, they could take solace in the rapid-fire news cycles of the Trump era. A crisis now may be long forgotten by November.
articles.abstract: As Democrats pushed the government toward a shutdown, they could take solace in the rapid-fire news cycles of the Trump era. A crisis now may be long forgotten by November.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the fall of 2013, Republican hard-liners engineered a 16-day shutdown of the federal government, implausibly insisting that President Barack Obama acquiesce to their demand that the Affordable Care Act be stripped of all funding.

articles.headline: How Trump and Schumer Came Close to a Deal Over Cheeseburgers
articles.snippet: The deal fell apart later in the day when the president and his chief of staff wanted more concessions on immigration.
articles.abstract: The deal fell apart later in the day when the president and his chief of staff wanted more concessions on immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump and Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the top Democrat in the Senate, came close to an agreement to avert a government shutdown over lunch on Friday. But their consensus broke down later in the day when the president and his chief of staff demanded more concessions on immigration, according to people on both sides familiar with the lunch and follow-up calls between Mr. Trump and Mr. Schumer.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Nicolle Wallace’s Road From the White House to 30 Rock
articles.snippet: How a former aide to George W. Bush and campaign strategist for John McCain’s 2008 presidential run has became a somewhat unlikely TV star at MSNBC.
articles.abstract: How a former aide to George W. Bush and campaign strategist for John McCain’s 2008 presidential run has became a somewhat unlikely TV star at MSNBC.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the basement of the Mexican restaurant Anejo TriBeCa last December, with rain pouring down on the streets of Lower Manhattan, Nicolle Wallace was addressing the staff of her new MSNBC show, “Deadline: White House.”

articles.headline: T. Boone Pickens, a Texas-Size Businessman, Calls It Quits
articles.snippet: A cantankerous self-made tycoon, Mr. Pickens shook up the oil business, promoted the concept of shareholder value and evangelized for renewable energy.
articles.abstract: A cantankerous self-made tycoon, Mr. Pickens shook up the oil business, promoted the concept of shareholder value and evangelized for renewable energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late last year, T. Boone Pickens was back at it, drilling for oil.

articles.headline: Bitter Bickering Muddies the Path to Ending the Government Shutdown
articles.snippet: With the government shut down and the two parties faulting each other, senators from both parties were looking for an agreement to end the crisis.
articles.abstract: With the government shut down and the two parties faulting each other, senators from both parties were looking for an agreement to end the crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the federal government one day into a shutdown, the House and Senate reconvened on Saturday for a new round of bitter partisan bickering and public posturing that seemed to cloud the path to a resolution despite initial talk of a compromise.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Congressman Combating Harassment Settled His Own Misconduct Case
articles.snippet: Representative Patrick Meehan, a Republican member of the House Ethics Committee, used taxpayer money to pay a former aide who had seen him as a father figure before he made unwanted advances.
articles.abstract: Representative Patrick Meehan, a Republican member of the House Ethics Committee, used taxpayer money to pay a former aide who had seen him as a father figure before he made unwanted advances.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Patrick Meehan, a Pennsylvania Republican who has taken a leading role in fighting sexual harassment in Congress, used thousands of dollars in taxpayer money to settle his own misconduct complaint after a former aide accused him last year of making unwanted romantic overtures to her, according to several people familiar with the settlement.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: Open, Closed or Something in Between: What a Shutdown Looks Like
articles.snippet: The vast machinery of the federal government began grinding to a halt, but much of the bureaucracy will stay in motion for a while.
articles.abstract: The vast machinery of the federal government began grinding to a halt, but much of the bureaucracy will stay in motion for a while.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A North Carolina National Guard infantry battalion called off a training exercise that had been planned for a year. Flu samples from around the country will no longer be collected and tested. A skeleton staff of workers at the Internal Revenue Service girded themselves to answer a deluge of questions about the new tax law.

articles.headline: How Corruption and Cronyism in Banking Fueled Iran’s Protests
articles.snippet: Thousands lost their savings in the collapse of shady banks, part of a broader economic system plagued by insider dealing, mismanagement and inefficiency.
articles.abstract: Thousands lost their savings in the collapse of shady banks, part of a broader economic system plagued by insider dealing, mismanagement and inefficiency.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — At 25 percent, the interest rate paid on a savings account at the Caspian Finance and Credit Institution in Tehran was a better return than Mehrdad Asgari could earn investing in his own business renting out construction equipment. So in December 2016, he jumped at the chance, depositing $42,000 in a savings account.
articles.byline: By Thomas Erdbrink, David D. Kirkpatrick and Nilo Tabrizy

articles.headline: 1 Son, 4 Overdoses, 6 Hours
articles.snippet: Drug deaths draw the most notice, but more addicted people live than die. For them and their families, life can be a relentless cycle of worry, hope and chaos.
articles.abstract: Drug deaths draw the most notice, but more addicted people live than die. For them and their families, life can be a relentless cycle of worry, hope and chaos.
articles.lead_paragraph: PEMBROKE, N.H. — The first time Patrick Griffin overdosed one afternoon in May, he was still breathing when his father and sister found him on the floor around 1:30. When he came to, he was in a foul mood and began arguing with his father, who was fed up with his son’s heroin and fentanyl habit.

articles.headline: Siege at Kabul Hotel Caps a Violent 24 Hours in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The Taliban attack at the Intercontinental Hotel left at least 18 dead, but the toll from assaults across four provinces of the country surpassed 50.
articles.abstract: The Taliban attack at the Intercontinental Hotel left at least 18 dead, but the toll from assaults across four provinces of the country surpassed 50.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban’s bloody, 14-hour siege on a major hotel in Kabul ended on Sunday, after six assailants terrorized much of the city with explosions and gunfire.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Fatima Faizi

articles.headline: Inside Amazon Go, a Store of the Future
articles.snippet: The technology inside Amazon’s new convenience store, opening Monday in downtown Seattle, enables a shopping experience like no other — including no checkout lines.
articles.abstract: The technology inside Amazon’s new convenience store, opening Monday in downtown Seattle, enables a shopping experience like no other — including no checkout lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The first clue that there’s something unusual about Amazon’s store of the future hits you right at the front door. It feels as if you are entering a subway station. A row of gates guard the entrance to the store, known as Amazon Go, allowing in only people with the store’s smartphone app.

articles.headline: Government Shutdown Goes Into Monday as Senate Inches Toward Deal
articles.snippet: Thousands of federal employees will be furloughed Monday morning even as the outlines of a potential compromise came into focus.
articles.abstract: Thousands of federal employees will be furloughed Monday morning even as the outlines of a potential compromise came into focus.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senators failed on Sunday to reach an agreement to end the government shutdown, ensuring that hundreds of thousands of federal employees would be furloughed Monday morning even as the outlines of a potential compromise came into focus.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: As Facebook Changes Its Feed, Advertisers See Video Ambitions
articles.snippet: The changes the social network recently made to its news feed has some advertisers thinking there will be opportunities for growth in video.
articles.abstract: The changes the social network recently made to its news feed has some advertisers thinking there will be opportunities for growth in video.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook made waves in the media industry with its recent announcement that it would put a new focus on “meaningful social interactions” with close friends and family in its News Feed — the column that people scroll through when they open the site — instead of content from publishers and brands.

articles.headline: Sundance, Steeped in Weinstein Mystique, Enters a New Era
articles.snippet: Harvey Weinstein helped put the Sundance Film Festival on the map. But organizers say this year’s slate, which puts women front and center, shows the festival has moved on.
articles.abstract: Harvey Weinstein helped put the Sundance Film Festival on the map. But organizers say this year’s slate, which puts women front and center, shows the festival has moved on.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — “Resist! Persist! Insist! Elect!”

articles.headline: There Is Nothing Virtual About Bitcoin’s Energy Appetite
articles.snippet: Creating a single token requires as much electricity as two years’ worth of consumption by an average American home. Some enthusiasts believe that’s a problem.
articles.abstract: Creating a single token requires as much electricity as two years’ worth of consumption by an average American home. Some enthusiasts believe that’s a problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Creating a new Bitcoin requires electricity. A lot of it.

articles.headline: Venezuela’s Most-Wanted Rebel Shared His Story, Just Before Death
articles.snippet: Óscar Pérez, the police officer who commandeered a helicopter and called on Venezuelans to rise up, spoke with The Times in the days and hours before he was killed.
articles.abstract: Óscar Pérez, the police officer who commandeered a helicopter and called on Venezuelans to rise up, spoke with The Times in the days and hours before he was killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The end had come for Óscar Pérez.

articles.headline: After #OscarsSoWhite, Hispanics Seek Their Hollywood Moment
articles.snippet: The last time a Hispanic actor was nominated for an Academy Award was 2012 and, according to a study, only 3 percent of speaking characters in films are Latino.
articles.abstract: The last time a Hispanic actor was nominated for an Academy Award was 2012 and, according to a study, only 3 percent of speaking characters in films are Latino.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After black actors and films that focused on black characters were overlooked for Oscar nominations in 2015 and 2016, the #OscarsSoWhite social media outcry was so fierce that Hollywood was forced to listen. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences began a determined diversification effort, and last year there were six black acting nominees, a record.

articles.headline: A President Not Sure of What He Wants Complicates the Shutdown Impasse
articles.snippet: Democrats struggle with a president who says he wants to compromise but then is reined in by his own staff, while Republican leaders are loath to guess at his intentions.
articles.abstract: Democrats struggle with a president who says he wants to compromise but then is reined in by his own staff, while Republican leaders are loath to guess at his intentions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump mused last year about protecting immigrants brought to the United States illegally as children, calling them “these incredible kids,” aides implored him privately to stop talking about them so sympathetically.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Tiny, Wealthy Qatar Goes Its Own Way, and Pays for It
articles.snippet: Among Persian Gulf states, Qatar was the picked-on little sibling. Gas riches and an independent-minded ruling family changed that. Now it’s in the fight of its life.
articles.abstract: Among Persian Gulf states, Qatar was the picked-on little sibling. Gas riches and an independent-minded ruling family changed that. Now it’s in the fight of its life.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — For the emir of Qatar, there has been little that money can’t buy.

articles.headline: Richemont, Doubling Down on Online Luxury, May Buy Yoox Net-a-Porter
articles.snippet: The Swiss conglomerate made a surprise $3.4 billion offer nearly three years after Yoox and Net-a-Porter merged in an all-share deal.
articles.abstract: The Swiss conglomerate made a surprise $3.4 billion offer nearly three years after Yoox and Net-a-Porter merged in an all-share deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Compagnie Financière Richemont built a conglomerate offering the world’s wealthiest consumers the highest-quality product, often in the most luxurious of settings. Clients walking into a Cartier flagship or a Piaget boutique — both Richemont brands — could expect radiant smiles and soft furnishings, as well as impeccable service for as long as was necessary before they made their purchase.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Paton and Chad Bray
